case_vignette: A 64-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered mental status. He was in his usual state of health until a few days ago when he has started to become confused, lethargic, forgetful, and repeating the same questions. Over the last few days, he sometimes appears perfectly normal, and, at other times, he has difficulty recognizing his family members. Yesterday, he was screaming that the room was filled with snakes. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed medically, and chronic kidney disease, for which he undergoes regular hemodialysis on alternate days. There is no history of smoking, alcohol use, or illicit drug use. His vitals include: blood pressure 129/88 mm Hg, pulse 112/min, temperature 38.2°C (100.8°F), and respiratory rate 20/min. The patient is oriented only to person and place. His mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 18/30, where he had difficulty performing basic arithmetic calculations and recalled only 1 out of 3 objects. Nuchal rigidity is absent. Muscle strength is 5/5 bilaterally.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really confused and tired lately, I keep forgetting things and asking the same questions over and over again.
Is this confusion and forgetfulness accompanied by any seizure activity?
No, I haven't had any seizures.

Have you noticed any changes in your vision or hearing abilities?

[Assuming the answer is negative, the final diagnosis could be: Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease with cognitive impairment, or Normal pressure hydrocephalus.]

Final Diagnosis: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (if the patient's gait is also affected) or Cognitive impairment not otherwise specified (if gait is normal).

   a. Normal aging process
   b. Depression
   c. Mild cognitive impairment
   d. Early dementia (Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, etc.)
   e. Infection (e.g., urinary tract infection, meningitis, or HIV)
   f. Medication side effects
   g. Other neurological conditions (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, etc.)
